pull.title: doc: Add fetching single PRs from upstream to productivity.md
pull.body:
Current recommendation is to add a new remote fetching all PRs, but this is resource-intensive.

Document a better way to fetch a single PR, and to update a PR which has been force-pushed.

Follows up on a [comment from 32774](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32774#discussion_r2156728913)

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--006a51241073e994b41acfe9ec718e94-->
### Code Coverage & Benchmarks
For details see: https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/32783.
<!--021abf342d371248e50ceaed478a90ca-->
### Reviews
See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process.
| Type | Reviewers |
| ---- | --------- |
| ACK | [pablomartin4btc](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32783#pullrequestreview-2954506359) |
| Concept ACK | [theStack](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32783#issuecomment-2990814501), [janb84](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32783#pullrequestreview-2945847224), [BrandonOdiwuor](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32783#pullrequestreview-2949866383) |

If your review is incorrectly listed, please react with 👎 to this comment and the bot will ignore it on the next update.
<!--5faf32d7da4f0f540f40219e4f7537a3-->
looks like there are typos (see llm linter), also left two more nits

verification.payload:
tree 053b10edd6dfd932b3fde3c3f2d6b175c8673bf9
parent 154b98a7aaae248f5d40ca567d1ec51410d09bae
author will <will@256k1.dev> 1750413949 +0100
committer will <will@256k1.dev> 1750418029 +0100

doc: Add fetching single PRs from upstream

Current recommendation is to add a new remote fetching all PRs, but this
is resource-intensive.

Document a better way to fetch a single PR, and to update a PR which has
been force-pushed.

events.message:
doc: Add fetching single PRs from upstream

Current recommendation is to add a new remote fetching all PRs, but this
is resource-intensive.

Document a better way to fetch a single PR, and to update a PR which has
been force-pushed.

events.body:
Hey, thanks for sharing this!
I’m still learning, but I found this update to the productivity.md doc really helpful. The idea of fetching PRs directly by number is something I didn’t know it is simple but powerful.
One thought: maybe mention that you need to have **upstream set as the main Bitcoin repo**, just in case someone hasn't done that yet.
Overall, this feels like a useful addition for newcomers like me. Appreciate it!
Concept ACK, great addition if you don't want to fetch all prs from the remote

ACK 83ccae194d0de3e64af54174898f030594be3a4f

In previous section ("Reference PRs easily with `refspec`s"), also touched recently in #32774, it could be mentioned that the user could use `git remove add`... instead of adding the remote manually into the git config file.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -185,6 +185,36 @@ As an alternative to fetching commits directly, when looking at pull requests by
 
 This will add an `upstream-pull` remote to your git repository, which can be fetched using `git fetch --all` or `git fetch upstream-pull`. It will download and store on disk quite a lot of data (all PRs, including merged and closed ones). Afterwards, you can use `upstream-pull/NUMBER/head` in arguments to `git show`, `git checkout` and anywhere a commit id would be acceptable to see the changes from pull request NUMBER.
 
+### Fetch and update PRs individually
+
+The refspec remote is quite resource-heavy, and it is possible to fetch PRs singularly from the remote. To to this you can run:
+
+```bash
+# Fetch
+git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head:pr-<number> && git switch pr-<number>
+
+# Update (even after force push)
+git fetch --update-head-ok -f upstream pull<number>/head:pr-<number>
comments.body:
```suggestion
git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head
```

Could either remove the branch creation, or mention that it optional?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -185,6 +185,36 @@ As an alternative to fetching commits directly, when looking at pull requests by
 
 This will add an `upstream-pull` remote to your git repository, which can be fetched using `git fetch --all` or `git fetch upstream-pull`. It will download and store on disk quite a lot of data (all PRs, including merged and closed ones). Afterwards, you can use `upstream-pull/NUMBER/head` in arguments to `git show`, `git checkout` and anywhere a commit id would be acceptable to see the changes from pull request NUMBER.
 
+### Fetch and update PRs individually
+
+The refspec remote is quite resource-heavy, and it is possible to fetch PRs singularly from the remote. To to this you can run:
+
+```bash
+# Fetch
+git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head:pr-<number> && git switch pr-<number>
+
+# Update (even after force push)
+git fetch --update-head-ok -f upstream pull<number>/head:pr-<number>
+```
+
+...from the command line, substituting `<number>` with the PR number you want to fetch/update.
+
+> [!NOTE]
+> We assume here that the `github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin.git` remote is called "upstream".
comments.body:
```suggestion
> The repository "upstream" must be the one that the pull requests was opened against.
```

could clarify for the gui repos as well and keep general?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -185,6 +185,37 @@ As an alternative to fetching commits directly, when looking at pull requests by
 
 This will add an `upstream-pull` remote to your git repository, which can be fetched using `git fetch --all` or `git fetch upstream-pull`. It will download and store on disk quite a lot of data (all PRs, including merged and closed ones). Afterwards, you can use `upstream-pull/NUMBER/head` in arguments to `git show`, `git checkout` and anywhere a commit id would be acceptable to see the changes from pull request NUMBER.
 
+### Fetch and update PRs individually
+
+The refspec remote is quite resource-heavy, and it is possible to fetch PRs singularly from the remote. To do this you can run:
+
+```bash
+# Individual fetch
+git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head
+
+# Fetch with automatic branch creation and switch
+git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head:pr-<number> && git switch pr-<number>
+```
comments.body:
```suggestion
git fetch origin pull/<number>/head

# Fetch with automatic branch creation and switch
git fetch origin pull/<number>/head:pr-<number> && git switch pr-<number>
```


NIT, lets align the remote names. 
Line 171 uses `origin`, lines 181 sets it to `upstream-pull` here we are using `upstream`. I think that if you just pull the repo the remote will default to `origin`?

comments.body:
> Line 171 uses `origin`, lines 181 sets it to `upstream-pull` here we are using `upstream`. I think that if you just pull the repo the remote will default to `origin`?

you can't use `origin`, as this is not the one the pull was opened against. upstream-pull is a different remote as well. It really needs to be a dedicated one for each repo

comments.body: (For reference, fetching by commit hash works across any repo in a GH repo network, so there it doesn't matter which remote is picked)

comments.body:
> > Line 171 uses `origin`, lines 181 sets it to `upstream-pull` here we are using `upstream`. I think that if you just pull the repo the remote will default to `origin`?
> 
> you can't use `origin`, as this is not the one the pull was opened against. upstream-pull is a different remote as well. It really needs to be a dedicated one for each repo

when i use the command as specified it fails:
```
bitcoin]$ git fetch upstream pull/32783/head
fatal: 'upstream' does not appear to be a git repository
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
```

when I use origin (this is my remote) this works
```
bitcoin]$ git remote -v
origin  https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin.git (fetch)
origin  https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin.git (push)
```

Did I miss a obvious step ?

@@ -185,6 +185,37 @@ As an alternative to fetching commits directly, when looking at pull requests by
 
 This will add an `upstream-pull` remote to your git repository, which can be fetched using `git fetch --all` or `git fetch upstream-pull`. It will download and store on disk quite a lot of data (all PRs, including merged and closed ones). Afterwards, you can use `upstream-pull/NUMBER/head` in arguments to `git show`, `git checkout` and anywhere a commit id would be acceptable to see the changes from pull request NUMBER.

comments.body:
@janb84 most developers here will have two remotes configured:

`origin`: _their personal fork_ of the repo they make changes in
`upstream`: the upstream repo you make PRs against

These are the most common names for them, but you can set them to be whatever you like.

If you just do `git clone https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin` it will set the remote to `origin` automagically (unless otherwise directed).

I'd prefer to avoid spelling this out in this document though. I think this is not a "git from scratch" guide, but more advanced tips for better productivity.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -185,6 +185,37 @@ As an alternative to fetching commits directly, when looking at pull requests by
 
 This will add an `upstream-pull` remote to your git repository, which can be fetched using `git fetch --all` or `git fetch upstream-pull`. It will download and store on disk quite a lot of data (all PRs, including merged and closed ones). Afterwards, you can use `upstream-pull/NUMBER/head` in arguments to `git show`, `git checkout` and anywhere a commit id would be acceptable to see the changes from pull request NUMBER.

comments.body:
> when I use origin (this is my remote) this works

I'd expect that normally `origin` refers to `your_user_name/bitcoin-core`, not to `bitcoin/bitcoin`.

This would give:

```
$ git fetch origin pull/32783/head
fatal: couldn't find remote ref pull/32783/head
```

Maybe, if all of this is more confusing than helpful, it could make sense to just omit it from the docs (and close this pull :sweat_smile: )

Fetching by commit id should work with any remote already, with the only downside of having to do two more clicks to copy the commit id.

comments.body:
you can just specify the specific source 

ie for this PR 
`git fetch https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin pull/32783/head` or
`git fetch https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin pull/32783/head:pr-32783 && git switch pr-32783`

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -185,6 +185,37 @@ As an alternative to fetching commits directly, when looking at pull requests by
 
 This will add an `upstream-pull` remote to your git repository, which can be fetched using `git fetch --all` or `git fetch upstream-pull`. It will download and store on disk quite a lot of data (all PRs, including merged and closed ones). Afterwards, you can use `upstream-pull/NUMBER/head` in arguments to `git show`, `git checkout` and anywhere a commit id would be acceptable to see the changes from pull request NUMBER.
 
+### Fetch and update PRs individually
+
+The refspec remote is quite resource-heavy, and it is possible to fetch PRs singularly from the remote. To do this you can run:
+
+```bash
+# Individual fetch
+git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head
+
+# Fetch with automatic branch creation and switch
+git fetch upstream pull/<number>/head:pr-<number> && git switch pr-<number>
+```
+
+...from the command line, substituting `<number>` with the PR number you want to fetch/update.
+
+> [!NOTE]
+> The remote named "upstream" here must be the one that the pull request was opened against.
+> e.g. github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin.git or for the GUI github.com/bitcoin-core/gui
comments.body: nit: looking at the comments around remotes, perhaps you can mention somewhere/ at the end of this note that users could check their setup with `git remote -v` (and maybe as you said, `git clone` adds the origin automatically - keeping in mind what you also said that this is not a git guide).
